answers: The Cultural Revolution [or Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution or Wénhuà dàgémìng; prompt on 1960s or 1970s]
Honoré de Balzac [accept Balzac and the Little Chinese Seamstress]
parts: Name this historical period which provides the background for the final section of the novel To Live, whose protagonist lives with an ox as his only companion after his daughter dies in childbirth.
References to the horrors of the Cultural Revolution are interspersed throughout this novel by Gao Xingjian ("sheeng-j'yen"), whose main characters are called "You" and "I."
In a novel by Dai Sijie ("see-j'yuh") set during the Cultural Revolution, two young boys gorge over forbidden novels from this French author's series The Human Comedy.

answers: Laplacian [or Laplace operator or del squared; do not accept or prompt on "del"]
parts: The stream function is constant along streamlines, which run tangent to this vector quantity. By Bernoulli's principle, holding potential energy constant and increasing pressure decreases this quantity.
The stream function can only be defined for two-dimensional flows with this property, meaning that the fluid's density remains constant.
The vorticity, which describes the rotation of a fluid, can be calculated as negative this operation applied to the stream function.

answers: Toynbee [accept Polly Toynbee, or Arnold Toynbee, or Toynbee Hall]
Hadrian [or Caesar Traianus Hadrianus; accept Hadrian's Wall]
parts: Name this British family. It produced an economic historian who lent his name to a "hall" which was London's first settlement house for the poor, and which inspired the work of Jane Addams in America.
Another member of the family, Arnold J. Toynbee, is best-known for this 12-volume work which traces the rise and fall of 19 civilizations and examines several "aborted" and "arrested" ones.

Yet another family member, Jocelyn Toynbee, was Britain's leading historian of Roman art; her first work focuses on sculpture from the era of this emperor, who built a wall from Solway Firth to the North Sea.

answers: Chinatown [or, more specifically, Los Angeles' Chinatown; prompt on Los Angeles]
parts: Name this place. At the end of that movie, detective Jake Gittes, played by Jack Nicholson, fails to prevent the police from killing Evelyn Mulwray in this place.
Chinatown is an example of the "neo-" variety of this kind of film. This term, which is usually applied to gritty crime dramas, comes from the fact that they were often shot in black-and-white.
This composer composed the score for Chinatown in only ten days. This man used the "blaster beam" to voice the character of V'Ger in his iconic score for Star Trek: The Motion Picture.

answers: malapropism [prompt on Mrs. Malaprop] (She is from The Rivals.)
lonely [accept lonely dragon or "I Wandered Lonely As a Cloud"]
parts: The name of these beings, which comes from a Czech word for "serf" or "laborer," was introduced to English by a Karel Čapek play in which Rossum invents them.
This word is named for a character who speaks of such concepts as "the very pineapple of politeness" and "an allegory on the banks of the Nile" to people such as Captain Absolute.

The first use of this adjective is in a Shakespeare speech in which Coriolanus describes himself as this sort of "dragon" in a fen. This adjective appears in the first line of a poem about objects which are "Continuous as the stars that shine / And twinkle on the milky way".

answers: conjugation [accept word forms like conjugate or conjugacy; accept complex conjugation]
symmetric groups [accept S sub n; prompt on Sn]
six [accept the symmetric group on six elements or equivalent phrasings, S6, or S sub 6]
parts: Name this operation that multiplies the elements of a group by an element and its inverse on opposite sides. The same word indicates sending a complex number a plus b i to a minus b i.
Elements of these groups are conjugate if and only if they have the same cycle structure. These groups of order n consist of the various permutations of the n elements.
Symmetric groups have only inner automorphisms except the one on this many elements, which has an outer automorphism due to an exotic embedding of the symmetric group on one fewer element.
Name this Washington D.C. university where students took part in the Deaf President Now protests. This university's football team invented the huddle.
This newspaper editor of the Argus and the Washington Globe donated land for Gallaudet University. This Kentucky-born politician was Postmaster General under Andrew Jackson.
In 2006, the Unity for Gallaudet Movement accused provost Jane Fernandes of being "not deaf enough" because she lacked fluency in this non-oral language.

answers: Juno [accept Iūnō; accept Juno Regina, Juno Moneta, or Juno Lucina; prompt on Sospita; prompt on Hera]
Neptune [accept Neptunus or Neptunus Equester; prompt on Poseidon]
parts: What goddess indirectly causes the attempted burning of the Trojan ships? The epithet omnipotens is given to her and her husband, Jupiter.
After Jupiter sends a rainstorm to quench the flames, this deity swears to protect the Trojan fleet. In Book I of the Aeneid, this deity saves the Trojan fleet from Aeolus's ("EE-oh-lus'z") winds.
The price for Neptune's aid is the death of this character, who is Aeneas's helmsman. In Book VI, his shade tells Aeneas how he washed ashore near Valia, where he was killed and left unburied.

answers: Western Australia (Western Australia's capital is Perth.)
coral [accept Coral Coast] (The ecosystem is the Great Barrier Reef.)
parts: Name this state. The mild Mediterranean climate between the Darling Scarp and the Indian Ocean created an ideal spot for its capital city.
Western Australia's mild climate makes it great for beachgoers in a "coast" named after this animal. The largest ecosystem in the world created by this animal is off of Queensland's coast.

Unlike most of Western Australia, this northernmost region of that state has a savannah-like climate influenced by the Indo-Australian tropical monsoon. It shares its name with an African city which is home to the "Big Hole," supposedly the deepest hole excavated by humans.
Name this Italian artist. Drawing on Vasari, Frederic Leighton ("LIGHT-un") misattributed a "celebrated Madonna" by this artist to Cimabue ("chee-MAH-boo-ay") in one of his paintings.
Duccio's Rucellai Madonna is currently held in this city's Uffizi ("oo-FEET-zee"), which were once the offices of its Medici family.

Duccio mainly worked in Siena, where he painted his version of this scene for the cathedral. Simone Martini painted the Virgin underneath a blue and red canopy surrounded by saints in his version of this scene, which has an Italian name.

answers: population density [accept density-dependence; I guess prompt on population size]
parts: K-selecting organisms tend to have population sizes near this quantity, the maximum amount of individuals that can be sustained in a given environment.

Factors that are "dependent" on this quantity are thus generally more significant to K-selecting organisms than r-selecting ones. Logistic population growth occurs in a manner "dependent" on this quantity.
r-selecting organisms tend to follow this type of survivorship curve. These concave-up curves involve many individuals dying early in their lifespan, with a few survivors living for a long time.

answers: Ghost Dance [or Nanissáanah; accept Ghost Dance of 1890]
Morning Star [prompt on Venus; do not accept or prompt on "Evening Star"; do not accept or prompt on just "star(s)"; accept Morning Star ceremony]
parts: Name this 19th century millenarian movement that believed that the namesake ritual would expel settlers and revive participants' ancestors.
The Ghost Dance held this celestial body to be the most sacred and used clothing with equal-armed crosses representing it. The Skidi Pawnee regularly sacrificed girls to this entity.
Ghost Dance leaders caused trances in dancers by waving fans made of these objects. A namesake law legalized Native Americans' religious use of these objects, such as in headdresses.
Name this city, which was the capital of a princely kingdom ruled by the Asaf Jahi dynasty. Its Salar Jung dynasty, whose rulers took the title of Nizam, founded a museum of curiosities in it.
Hyderabad's Golconda mines were once the world's only source of these objects, one of which known as the Koh-i-Noor was placed on the Peacock Throne.

The Nizams once paid tribute to this empire that dominated the Deccan Plateau. Founded by Shivaji, it overtook the Mughals as a regional power and fought three wars with the British in the late 1700s.
Give this genre of the soft pieces collected in Frédéric Chopin's Opus 9. The best-known of that set of these pieces is the second, which is in E-flat major and 12/8 ("twelve-eight") time.
The Nocturne Op. 9, No. 2 makes heavy use of turns on this note, whose major key signature lacks both sharps and flats.

Near its end, the Nocturne Op. 9 No. 2 includes a passage marked by this term, indicating that the piece should quickly accelerate toward a climax. In fugues, this term indicates the start of an imitation of a subject before the subject is completed.

answers: the great chain of being [prompt on chain]
parts: Name this didactic poem which describes its central subject as "Plac'd on this isthmus of a middle state / A being darkly wise, and rudely great". It states that pride is found "in erring reason's spite".
An Essay on Man is by this British poet of the satirical epics The Rape of the Lock and The Dunciad.

An Essay on Man states that this concept "draws all to agree" and asks the reader whether it is "upheld by God, or Thee?" A book by Arthur Lovejoy examines the history of this medieval idea of a hierarchy of creation.
Name this man, who went door-to-door in St. Luke's parish to trace that outbreak to the Broad Street pump. He is considered to be one of the fathers of epidemiology.
The aforementioned 1854 cholera outbreak occurred in this city. A 1665-1666 plague that struck this city was coincident with a "Great Fire" in it.

Max von Pettenkofer downed a bouillon laced with cholera in order to prove the Miasma Theory to this scientist. This scientist's examination of cholera outbreaks in Calcutta and Alexandria helped him quell an 1892 cholera outbreak in Hamburg.

answers: stock dividends [accept dividend discount model; prompt on cash flows]
WACC [or weighted average cost of capital; prompt on cost of capital or discount rate or interest rate or average interest rate; do not accept or prompt on "capital"]
parts: A common way of valuing stocks is by summing up the discounted value of these payments across the entire future time horizon, known as their namesake "discount model".

To figure out how to discount the dividends, you find a company with similar cash flow risk and compute this value. For a company with a given risk, this value represents the average expected return on investment for equity and debt holders.
Maybe you don't want to buy stonks at all, since you're in one of these down-trending markets named for an animal. They're contrasted with "bull markets".

answers: London dispersion forces (accept either underlined portion) [prompt on van der Waals forces]
parts: Name this model for the potential energy between two non-bonded atoms or molecules. It is sometimes called the "6-12" potential, referencing how its terms vary with distance.
The 6th-power, attractive term in the Lennard-Jones potential represents these intermolecular forces, which form between an instantaneous dipole and an induced dipole.
The strength of the London dispersion force between two non-identical molecules is proportional to the product of their polarizabilities times the harmonic mean of this quantity.
Name this photographer who accidentally invented spirit photography after a self-portrait he took had the silhouette of a girl in the background.
This man was one of the people who testified against Mumler after he was arrested as a fraud. One of this man's own hoaxes involved the Fiji Mermaid, which was half-monkey and half-fish.
To prove Mumler a fraud, Barnum created a photograph of himself with this person. Mumler had earlier taken a spirit photograph with this person's "ghost" standing behind his wife Mary Todd.
Name this man whose official English biography was written by Ernest Jones, who became the first English practitioner of psychoanalysis, a discipline this man invented.

Critics of Gay and Jones's biographies of Freud have labeled them with this term, which refers to biographies of figures such as Catherine of Siena. Many medieval ones are collected in The Golden Legend.
With Stephen Marcus, this author compiled an abridged version of Jones's biography. His best-known essay collection, which includes "Freud and Literature", is titled The Liberal Imagination.
